div1.head: Abstract Notes: The Ill-Fated Typhoid Experiments, by [Philip Showalter Hench?], [19--]
div1.p:
ABSTRACT OF DATA CONCERNING THE ILL_FATED TYPHOID EXPERIMENTS
OF DR. JAMES CARROLL
(Material in Peabody collection)

Letter from Major General H. L. Gilchrist to Senator Copeland, Feb. 25, 1925,
favoring legislative action on behalf of Mr. George S. Ward.

Copy of Bill S 3425, 73rd Congress, Second Session. Apparently, this was
later changed to S 45, 74th Congress, First Session, on behalf of a pension for
Mr. Ward.
Summary by Dr. Philip Matz regarding official memoranda about these experiments.
Letters from H. L. Gilchrist, then a Colonel, April 14, 1928 and Jan. 30, 1934.

In May, 1904, James Carroll, then First Lieutenant, and Director of Laboratories
in the Army Medical School proposed the vaccination of soldiers by the oral administra-
tion of a suspension of dead typhoid bacilli. With the approval of his superiors,
Dr. Carroll called for volunteers. Ten men were selected, including Lt. James
Carroll, Lt. H. L. Gilchrist and others, including Private George S. Ward. Before
the experiments began, those volunteers requested to be released, as they had a
presentiment that something was going to happen. Dr. Carroll assembled the volunteers,
explained the matter and in order to encourage the men to carry out the experiment,
Lts. Gilchrist and Vedder (Carroll's assistant) took much larger doses than pre-
scribed. Following this, each man lined up and took a dose. Results were that
several of the men developed typhoid fever as a result of a technical failure to
have the material thoroughly sterilized. Lt. Carroll did not have typhoid fever as he had
already had it but seven of the men had undoubted attacks of typhoid fever. There
were no deaths. The records of the men who became ill are given. Few investigations
were made as the diagnosis seemed definite and “it was decided to give no undue
publicity to these cases.”
